\question[2] Suppose I observe the prices and total quantities of coffee traded in a market from the years 1990-2010. Suppose I plot a line through these points (e.g., a line that minimises the sum of squared distances between the line and these points. This line (choose all that are correct):

\question[4] A simple idea attributed to Adam Smith is that if it takes twice as long to hunt a deer as a beaver, a deer should trade for two beavers in the marketplace.
Considering this, which of the following are valid critiques of the limitations of this as a model of the determination of price and quantity (select all that apply):
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item Hunters who have more beavers than deer would refuse to trade at these prices.
\item This alone does not tell us how many deers and beavers will be traded.
\item The amount of time it takes to hunt a deer versus a beaver may depend on how many have already been caught.
\item There are inputs into the production process other than labour which may affect the price.
\item No one would ever hunt beavers at these prices.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{solution}
b, c, and d are valid critiques.


b, c, and d are valid critiques. 

a. 'Hunters who have more beavers than deer would refuse to trade at these prices.' This is not true. If hunters need more of either good for their own consumption than they have hunted (e.g., suppose each are 'necessities'), they will trade these in the market. (Note that  given the implied 'production function' at these prices, the hunter couldn't do any better by reallocating her hours instead of trading.) Also, we can imagine this example in terms of prices in some baseline currency which could be used for other goods... the hunter may want to sell her kill to buy these other goods, and if these are the prices she faces, she will do so.


b. True, this *is* a limitation. The above claim only tells us about the relative price of these 2 goods, perhaps reflecting a supply curve, perhaps a demand curve, but it doesn't tell us the quantity exchanged. However many are traded, this statement only tells us at what 'rate' they are traded.

\

c.  Yes, there may be diminishing returns to labour (hunting) in each good as the stock of each animal is used up. This is an important part of the supply/demand model, implying an upwards sloping supply curve. If each deer is more and more (time) costly to hunt, only a higher price will induce hunters to supply more in aggregate.


d. True, there may be capital inputs (e.g., guns and ammo) and land inputs (the hunting grounds), as well as  transportation costs, fuel etc. E.g., it might be that it takes twice as long to hunt a deer as a beaver but it costs less in 'capital', as the cost of the ammunition and gun maintenance per additional deer is less than the cost of maintaining beaver traps per additional beaver (when using the optimal mix of inputs).


\end{solution}

\question[4] Suppose an individual has indifference curves between steak and wine that illustrate a diminishing marginal rate of substitution everywhere.
Assume her optimal consumption involves buying a positive amount of both goods.
At her current consumption plan, her MRS (of wine for steak) is 1/4.

\end{solution}

Question text: True or false: Most economists believe we do not observe utility directly, but we can make inferences about preferences based on observed choices.
latex: \question[1] True or false: Most economists believe we do not observe utility directly, but we can make inferences about preferences based on observed choices.
Extended answer: True. We do not typically assume there is a biological measure of  utility,  and we allow that people make choices (subject to their constraints) for variety of reasons and motivations. The assumption of utility maximization essentially requires that people can make choices between any combinations and weigh the trade-offs of each of these in a unified framework.  The utility maximization framework also imposes some restriction on choices in the sense that when someone chooses a more expensive option over a cheaper one,it  must be that the more expensive option is preferred, i.e., it yields more additional utility. Thus we can make inferences about preferences based observing what people choose.\end{solution}

Question text:
6. . Suppose an individual’s MRS (of steak for beer) is 1:2. That is, at the current consumption choices he or she is willing to give up 1 beer to get an extra 2 steaks, (or half a beer to get another steak). Suppose also that the price of a steak is £2 and a beer is 50p. Then in order to increase (or maximise) utility the individual should
  a.  buy more steak and less beer.
  b.  buy more beer and less steak.
  c.  continue with current consumption plans.
  d.  Not enough information to answer the question.
Extended answer:
Let's skip the formulae and just reason. At her current level of consumption, steak is twice as valuable to her as beer (per unit), yet it costs *four times* as much per unit. At the margin, every pound she spends, she can buy one steak or four beers; the latter would yield twice as much utility.
This means she should buy more beer and less steak. The MU of beer will decline, and the MU of steak will increase ... and she should keep making this shift until the rate she is willing to trade off steak to obtain beer is '1 steak per 4 beers', reflecting the price ratio.

\question[3] Which of the following weights on utility (over four periods starting with the current one)
provide an illustration of hyperbolic discounting that could well lead to inconsistent choices over time?
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
  \item  1, .5, .25, .125.
  \item  1, .8, .72, .648.
  \item  1, .25, .0625, .015625.
  \item  1, 1, 1, 1
  \item None of the above
\end{enumerate}

\begin{solution}
b.  1, .8, .72, .648. Note that this implies nonconstant weighting of future periods, as (e.g., 0.8*0.8 = 0.64 \neq 0.72. \end{solution}

\question[4] Consider a version of the ultimatum game in which player A makes an integer offer \{1,2,\dots,9\} to player B.
If B accepts, he or she gets that amount of money and A gets to keep the remainder of \pounds 10.
If B rejects, both get nothing. Consider the following particular preferences.
Players get 1 unit of utility ('util') per pound they earn. For player A this represents her entire utility. However, player B is extremely competitive, and in addition to 1 util per pound he earns he also loses 2 utils if he does not have strictly \textit{greater} payoffs than player A (unless both get 0  material payoffs, in which case he gets a 0 material payoff). Both players are aware of each other's preferences. Which of the following is an offer that arises in a subgame-perfect equilibrium with these preferences? Remember that in considering a Nash Equilibrium, we can `assume' that players who are indifferent between rejecting an offer and accepting it will accept it.

\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
\item \pounds 1.
\item \pounds 2.
\item \pounds 4.
\item \pounds 5.
\item \pounds 6.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{solution}
In this case, B the second player will accept an offer if either
1. he has greater payoffs than the other player, and these payoffs are positive, or
2. B has lower payoffs than A, but B's payoffs are greater than or equal to 2.

For the first case, A must offer at least 6, so that B has 'greater payoffs' than A. That leaves A with 4, of course.
For the second case, A must offer at least 2, which B will accept, leaving A with 8.  A will prefer this. This pairing of strategies is a SPNE.
(and of course, if A leaves less than 2 to B, B rejects and neither get anything.)
\end{solution}

\question[3] {\textit{There are between 1 and 5 correct answers; partial credit will be awarded.}}  Consider how prospect theory (PT) differs from the standard theory of expected utility (EU-theory)? Which of the following are correct? (Choose all that apply).
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
  \item  Under EU theory, an individual compares gambles based on the sum of the VnM utility of each outcome weighted by its actual probability. Under PT, individuals may overweight or underweight a 'prospect' relative to it's true probability. 
\item  Under PT, an individual may evaluate a 'prospect' based on the variance of the monetary outcomes, while under EU-theory, an individual will always choose the investment with the greatest expected monetary value.
  \item Under EU-theory, an individual must be always equally risk-averse, risk-loving, or risk-neutral when considering a gamble relative to ANY level of wealth, while under PT an individual can be very risk-averse starting from a low level of wealth, but then less risk-averse, or even risk-loving, when starting from a higher wealth level.
  \item  With PT, an individual who finds herself with wealth \pounds 5000 may be willing to take a fair gamble if the \pounds 5000 wealth is percieved as a `loss relative to a reference point' but this same person might not be willing to take the same fair gamble if the \pounds 5000 were at or above the 'reference point.' Under EU-theory, this could never be the case; a 'reference point' will not affect decisions 
  \item Under EU-theory, an individual will always be \emph{Prudent}, while under PT, she will never be \emph{Prudent}.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{solution}
 Under EU theory, an individual compares gambles based on the sum of the VnM utility of each outcome weighted by its actual probability. Under Prospect Theory, individuals may overweight or underweight a 'prospect' relative to it's true probability.  (remember that this is one of the two main elements of Prospect Theory) AND
\bigskip 
 With prospect theory, an individual who finds herself with wealth \pounds 5000 may be willing to take a fair gamble if the \pounds 5000 wealth is percieved as a `loss relative to a reference point' but this same person might not be willing to take the same fair gamble if the \pounds 5000 were at or above the 'reference point.' Under EU-theory, this could never be the case; a 'reference point' will not affect decisions. (This is the other key element of PT)
\bigskip 
The other claims are false. Under EU-theory an individual can have any risk attitude, and it need not be constant for all levels of wealth. Under EU-theory she may or may not be Prudent (and this can also vary over the range of wealth levels.)  



\end{solution}

\question[8] \textcolor{black}{\textit{There are between 1 and 5 correct answers; partial credit will be awarded.}} Suppose that shepherd A and B simultaneously choose how many sheep to graze on the commons.  Shepherd A gets benefit $s_A(120-2s_A-s_B)$ and B gets benefit $s_B(120-2s_A-s_B)$, where $s_A$ and $s_B$ are the number of sheep grazed by shepherds A and B, respectively.

\bigskip

Considering the best-responses and Nash equilibrium of this game (you may need to compute these), which of the following are true?

%Is this an outcome that maximises the sum of the benefits (for both countries)? Explain.

\begin{enumerate}[label=(\Alph*)]  \item Considering best responses, the more sheep A grazes, the more shepherd B will graze, and vice-versa (within the range where both graze positive amounts).
  \item Considering best responses, the more A grazes, the less B will graze, and vice-versa (within the range where both graze positive amounts).
  \item Under Nash equilibrium play,  A will graze as much as or more than B.
  \item Under Nash equilibrium play, the total number of sheep grazed (summed across both shepherds) is less than 50.
  \item Under Nash equilibrium play, the total benefits (summed across both shepherds) are at less than half of their maximum possible level (considering any level of grazing that could be agreed upon, if an agreement could be enforced).
 \end{enumerate}

\begin{solution}

Correct answer:

[only ONE] Considering best responses, the more A grazes, the less B will graze, and vice-versa (within the range where both graze positive amounts).

AND

%Under Nash equilibrium play, the total benefits (summed across both shepherds) are at less than half of their maximum possible level (considering any level of grazing that could be agreed upon, if an agreement could be enforced).

\bigskip

\textit{Explanation}

Solving for best responses, we take the FOC (set derivatives equal to 0)

to get, for shepherd A:
$120-2s_A-s_B-2s_A=0$ $\rightarrow$ $120-4s_A=s_B \rightarrow 4s_A=120-s_B \rightarrow s_A=30-s_B/4$

For shepherd B this yields $(120-2s_A-s_B)-s_B=0$ $\rightarrow$ $120-2s_A=2s_B$ $\rightarrow s_B=60-s_A$.

So `Considering best responses, the more shepherd A grazes, the less shepherd B will graze, and vice-versa.'


Plugging these in, $s_A^{ne}=30 - (60-s_A)/4 = 30-15+s_A/4 \rightarrow (3/4)s_A = 15 \rightarrow s_A^{ne} = 60/3=20$

Plugging in to B's BR: $s_B^{ne}=60-20=40$

(So `Under Nash equilibrium play, A will graze as much as or more than shepherd B' is FALSE.)

Total sheep grazed NE are thus $s_A+s_B=20+40=60$

(so `Under Nash equilibrium play, the total number of sheep grazed (summed across both shepherds) is less than 50' is FALSE)

The total benefit in general is $s_A(120-2s_A-s_B) +  s_B(120-2s_A-s_B)$.

Under NE this is $20(120-2\times20-40)+40(120-2\times20-40)=20(40)+40(40)=2400$.

Considering the optimum provision, we have to optimize over two variables, with potentially binding non-negativity constraints. To keep it simple, let's use intuition.

The total benefit in general is $s_A(120-2s_A-s_B) +  s_B(120-2s_A-s_B)$.

Consider the marginal benefit of either adding a sheep: 
$MB_A= 120-4s_A-3s_B$
$MB_B= 120-3s_A-2s_B$


For any level of grazing by either ($s_A$ and $s_B$), 'A grazing an additional sheep' always yields less additional net value than does 'B grazing an additional sheep'.  Thus, it is clear that B `doing all the grazing' will lead to the greatest level of total benefit. So, set $S_B=0$. This yields a much simpler maximisation: 

$s_B= argmax [s_B(120-s_B)]$. Clearly this is just 'maximising a rectangle's area.' The FOC yields an optimum where $120-2s_B=0$ $\rightarrow$ $s_B^{opt}=60$ (and $s_A^{opt}=0$). Note that in this case this is the same total level of grazing as in the NE, but the sheep are allocated to the more efficient shepherd.  

%Setting $s_A$ to maximize this implies $120-4s_A-3s_B=0$, so  $4s_A+3s_B=120$ $\rightarrow s_A=30-(3/4)s_B$. (We can already see that this is less than the amount specified in A's BRF.)

%Setting $s_B$ to maximize this implies $120-3s_A-2s_B=0$, so  $3s_A+2s_B=120$ $\rightarrow 2s_B=120-3s_A \rightarrow s_B=60-(3/2)s_A$

%Plugging this in: $s_B=60-(3/2)(30-(3/4)s_B)= 60-45+(9/8)s_B$ $\rightarrow (1/8)s_B=$ $\rightarrow s_B^{opt}=40$.

%Plugging in yields $s_A^{opt}=30-(3/4)40=0$.

This yields payoffs $0+60 \times (120-60)=3600$.

These benefits are greater than before, but less than twice as high (2400 vs 3600). This is arguably an example of the tragedy of the commons; the individual and group incentives are not aligned; however, redistribution of the output would be necessary for both parties to benefit from this optimal structure.

\end{solution}

\begin{minipage}{\linewidth}
  \question[5]  \textcolor{black}{\textit{There are between 1 and 5 correct answers; partial credit will be awarded.}}   Which of the following are FALSE?

\begin{enumerate}[label=(\Alph*)]  \item Both second and third-degree price discrimination will always lead to a greater quantity exchanged.
  \item For third-degree price discrimination to improve total welfare it must lead to an increase in the quantity exchanged (this is a necessary condition)
\item The ability to price discriminate may reduce the profits of a monopolist
  \item Under second-degree price discrimination the consumer who values the good MORE than th other consumer will purchase less than the efficient quantity or quality of the good
  \item Both second and third-degree price discrimination involve self-selection by on the basis consumers, as the firm cannot identify any attributes of the consumer in either case without the consumer voluntarily disclosing these
 \item Price discrimination based on cookies and 'time of arrival' on a webpage will be perfect price discrimination
\end{enumerate}

\begin{solution}

Only one statement is true, the remainder are false. (With these instructions, be sure to fill in the bubbles for the false statements only)

FALSE: 'The ability to price discriminate may reduce the profits of a monopolist.'

Note that the ability to price discriminate will never reduce the monopoly's profits, and will potentially allow these to increase. Remember, the firm could always ignore this tool if it is not helpful.

\bigskip 

FALSE: 'Under second-degree price discrimination the consumer who values the good MORE than the other consumer will purchase less than the efficient quantity or quality of the good'

No, it is the reverse. The quality/quantity are distorted downwards for the consumer who values the good LESS; this is to prevent the more valuable consumer from choosing this cheaper bundle.

\bigskip 

FALSE: 'Both second and third-degree price discrimination involve self-selection by on the basis consumers, as the firm cannot identify any attributes of the consumer in either case without the consumer voluntarily disclosing these'

This describes second-degree price discrimination but not third-degree price discrimination, where the category of consumer CAN be identified

\bigskip 

FALSE: 'Price discrimination based on cookies and 'time of arrival' on a webpage will be perfect price discrimination.'

This may combine second and third-degree price discrimination and it may yield a different price being paid by each consumer. However, this will not allow the seller to perfectly mind read and determine every consumers exact willingness to pay.

\bigskip 

TRUE:   'For third-degree price discrimination to improve total welfare it must lead to an increase in the quantity exchanged (this is a necessary condition)

As 3dpd reduces exchange efficiency (some people may obtain the good who value it less than others who do not obtain the good), we need an increase in quantity (improving top-level efficiency) to potentially make up for this.

\end{minipage}

\question[4]  \textcolor{black}{\textit{Choose ALL that are TRUE.}}
Consider the choice between two binary lotteries $A$ and $B$. Lottery $A$ will pay $A_1$ with probability $p$ and $A_0$ with probability $1-p$, where $A_1>A_0$. Lottery $B$ will pay $B_1$ with probability $q$ and $B_0$ with probability $1-q$, where $B_1>B_0$. Each lottery costs the same amount to obtain. Assume all people prefer more money to less money. Which of the following is/are true?

\begin{enumerate}[label=(\Alph*)]  
\item If $p=1/2$ and $q=1/4$, and $A_0=B_0=0$, a risk-neutral person will choose lottery $A$ if $A_1>2B_1$.
\item If $p=1/2$ and $q=1/4$, and $A_0=B_0=0$, a risk-averse person will choose lottery $A$ if $A_1>2B_1$.
\item If $p=1/2$, $q=1/4$, $A_0=B_0=0$, and $B_1=2A_1$ a risk-averse person will definitely choose lottery $A$.
  \item A risk-averse person will always choose the lottery with the lower payoff variance, regardless of expected monetary value.
  \item A risk-loving person will always choose the lottery with the greater variance.
 \end{enumerate}
\begin{solution}
TRUE: If $p=1/2$ and $q=1/4$, and $A_0=B_0=0$, a risk-neutral person will choose lottery $A$ if $A_1>2B_1$.
If this is the case, it has a greater expected monetary value, so a risk neutral person would prefer it.
\bigskip 
AND
TRUE: If $p=1/2$, $q=1/4$, $A_0=B_0=0$, and $B_1=2A_1$ a risk-averse person will definitely choose lottery $A$.
If this is the case, the expected values are the same but lottery A has less variation in payoffs, so a risk-averse person will choose it.

\bigskip 
The remaining statements are false. Both risk-averse people and risk lovers care both about the expected value and about the variation in payoffs. (The difference is that risk-averse people prefer less variation in payoffs and risk lovers prefer more variation in payoffs)

\end{solution}

\end{minipage}

\begin{minipage}{\linewidth}
\question[4] \textcolor{black}{\textit{There are between 1 and 5 correct answers; partial credit will be awarded.}} According to modern microeconomic theory, which of the following situations may  lead to a departure from efficiency
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\Alph*)]
\item Uncertainty: 'coin flip' risk outcomes combined with different levels of risk aversion.
\item A single firm that can exclude other firms from entering, but which cannot price discriminate. 
\item Information is asymmetric: sellers know more about the quality of a product sold than potential buyers do (and the true quality of a product cannot be directly contracted upon).
\item In many business relationships one firm controls the level of efforts/costs put into a joint project, and the other firm does not have direct control over this. However, a complete contract can be written over these costs.
\item In many employment relationships the employeee controls the level of effort she puts in, but the employer cannot observe this, only observing the outcome. Employees are generally more  risk-averse than their employers.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{solution}
YES: A single firm that can exclude other firms from entering, but which cannot price discriminate. $\rightarrow$ this can lead to the deadweight loss of monopoly.

YES: Information is asymmetric: sellers know more about the quality of a product sold than potential buyers do, and the true quality of a product cannot be directly contracted upon. -- this is an example of the 'Lemons problem' 

YES: In many employment relationships the employeee controls the level of effort she puts in, but the employer cannot observe this, only observing the outcome. Employees are generally more  risk-averse than their employers. -- this is the classic 'Moral Hazard' problem



NOT: Uncertainty: 'coin flip' risk outcomes combined with different levels of risk aversion. If information is symmetric and markets for taking on/hedging risk exist, we can attain a first best outcome.

NOT: In many business relationships one firm controls the level of efforts/costs put into a joint project, and the other firm does not have direct control over this. However, a complete contract can be written over these costs. -- Here effort costs are both observable and contractible, so neither faces risk and limited liability should not be a issue

\end{solution}
\end{minipage}
